thread.title: Review: Carrie Underwood a little more personal on new album
thread.title_full: Review: Carrie Underwood a little more personal on new album

author: wtopstaff
title: Review: Carrie Underwood a little more personal on new album
text:
Home » News » Entertainment » Music » Review: Carrie Underwood a… Review: Carrie Underwood a little more personal on new album By MICHAEL McCALL October 22, 2015 4:32 pm In this Sept. 28, 2015 photo, Carrie Underwood poses for a portrait at Sony Music Nashville in Nashville, Tenn., to promote her latest album, "Storyteller." (Photo by Donn Jones/Invision/AP) 
Carrie Underwood, “Storyteller” (Arista Nashville) 
“Storyteller” is Carrie Underwood’s first album in three years — and her first since becoming a mother. That life-changing event rises most overtly on the touching “What I Never Knew I Always Wanted,” a beautiful song that delves into the life-altering changes new parents undergo. 
The maturing process of marriage and motherhood also influenced the yearning “The Girl You Think I Am,” about wanting to live up to her parents’ expectations, and the ballad “Like I’ll Never Love You Again,” one of her most passionate love songs to date. 
For the first time since her debut album 10 years ago, Underwood teams with more than one producer. Longtime collaborator Mark Bright works on five of the 13 songs, including the murderous revenge tale “Church Bells.” Hot Nashville producer Jay Joyce helms six songs, including the hit single “Smoke Break” and the swampy, southern gothic “Choctaw County Affair,” which pushes Underwood into a soulful new sound. 
Much of the rest of “Storyteller” sticks with Underwood’s penchant for dramatic tales with big choruses, including two cuts produced by young, pop-country producer Zach Crowell. The result is an album that balances Underwood’s proven strengths with songs that show artistic growth by drawing more on the singer’s personal life. Topics:
